questions.question_text:
Your application provides data transformation services. Files containing data to be transformed are first uploaded to Amazon S3 and then transformed by a fleet of spot EC2 instances. Files submitted by your premium customers must be transformed with the highest priority.
How should you implement such a system?

choices.C: Use two SQS queues, one for high priority messages, the other for default priority. Transformation instances first poll the high priority queue; if there is no message, they poll the default priority queue.
choices.A: Use a DynamoDB table with an attribute defining the priority level. Transformation instances will scan the table for tasks, sorting the results by priority level.
choices.D: Use a single SQS queue. Each message contains the priority level. Transformation instances poll high-priority messages first.
choices.B: Use Route 53 latency based-routing to send high priority tasks to the closest transformation instances.

discussion.content:
simple answer: c

http://jayendrapatil.com/aws-sqs-simple-queue-service/

C. Use two SQS queues, one for high priority messages, the other for default priority. Transformation instances first poll the high priority queue; if there is no message, they poll the default priority queue.

Selected Answer: C
simple answer: c
C. directly from jon bonso's exam
C is correct
C is correct.
easy one for SQS, C, hope I can have it in my exam

C
Classical solution
Answer is C.

questions.question_text: Which of the following are characteristics of Amazon VPC subnets? (Choose two.)

choices.B: Each subnet maps to a single Availability Zone.
choices.A: Each subnet spans at least 2 Availability Zones to provide a high-availability environment.
choices.C: CIDR block mask of /25 is the smallest range supported.
choices.E: Instances in a private subnet can communicate with the Internet only if they have an Elastic IP.
choices.D: By default, all subnets can route between each other, whether they are private or public.

discussion.content:
B. Each subnet maps to a single Availability Zone.
D. By default, all subnets can route between each other, whether they are private or public.
BD is correct, but default all subnets within a VPC can communicate with each other.

B and D are correct
B: he first entry is the default entry for local routing in the VPC; this entry enables the instances ( from private or public) in this VPC to communicate with each other.
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vpc/latest/userguide/VPC_Scenario2.html
16 IPs is the smallest range for a VPC Subnet -- /28

Of course it's BD
E is wrong, without igw, a subnet can't communicate with internet.
And a private subnet has no igw

piotr Highly Voted 1 year, 8 months ago
Subnet is always a single AZ. BD is correct answer.

questions.question_text: In AWS, which security aspects are the customer's responsibility? (Choose four.)

choices.B: Amazon S3 is engineered for 99.999999999% durability. Therefore there is no need to confirm that data was inserted.
choices.D: Each S3 account has a special bucket named _s3_logs. Success codes are written to this bucket with a timestamp and checksum.
choices.C: A success code is inserted into the S3 object metadata.
choices.A: A HTTP 200 result code and MD5 checksum, taken together, indicate that the operation was successful.

discussion.content:
A
http://jayendrapatil.com/aws-simple-storage-service-s3-overview/
A. A HTTP 200 result code and MD5 checksum, taken together, indicate that the operation was successful.
A. A HTTP 200 result code and MD5 checksum, taken together, indicate that the operation was successful.
Yes A is correct

A:

questions.question_text: When you put objects in Amazon S3, what is the indication that an object was successfully stored?

questions.answer_description:
Use groups to assign permissions to IAM users
Instead of defining permissions for individual IAM users, it's usually more convenient to create groups that relate to job functions (administrators, developers, accounting, etc.), define the relevant permissions for each group, and then assign IAM users to those groups. All the users in an IAM group inherit the permissions assigned to the group. That way, you can make changes for everyone in a group in just one place. As people move around in your company, you can simply change what IAM group their IAM user belongs to.
Reference:
http://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/best-practices.html#use-groups-for-permissions

choices.C: There's no GROUP in IAM, but only USERS and RESOURCES.
choices.B: It's the group of EC2 machines that gain the permissions specified in the GROUP.

questions.question_text: Within the IAM service a GROUP is regarded as a:
